pulltitle: Explicitly guard against port <= 0 in URL validation
pullsbody:
The url parser itself will not accept negative port values, but it allows zero.  So we may as well put in a full explicit check for ourselves.  This also copies over some testcases from the urlparse library, which naturally identified a bug in the port-handling code anyway...

@vladikoff r?
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Explicitly guard against port <= 0 in URL validation

pulltitle: Cache checks on whether to use a proxy, rather than checking each time.
pullsbody:
Sorry @mostlygeek, but you sent me down a Freaky Friday rabbit hole...

Here's something that might help with the CPU usage issue identified in https://github.com/mozilla/browserid-verifier/issues/80.  The current code checks for and validates proxy-related environment variables on every remote request.  This version generates a specialized checking function based on the current env var values, and only changes it if it finds that the env vars have mysteriously changed.

In a simple local test calling `shouldUseProxy` 1000000 times in a loop, this version is very slightly slower when there's no `HTTPS_PROXY` env var, and more than five times faster when there is.

Kinda complicated, but good fun and might be worth it to save a few pennies a day :-P
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Cache checks on whether to use a proxy, rather than checking each time.

pullsbody:
@fmarier this removes some additional uses of the old `urlparse` module, replacing them with some straightforward extra checks on the result of the builtin `url.parse` function.  I'm going to merge and release it when travis goes green, because I forgot to do this as part of the v0.3.0 release, so current release version is busted :-(

But if you get a chance, an r? would still be appreciated.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Remove additional uses of 'urlparse' module

pulltitle: Allow IdPs to publish multiple public keys.
pullsbody:
This allows the IdP support document to include a 'keys' property containing a list of public keys, any of which could be used to produce a valid signature.  IdPs might like to use this during e.g. key rotation events.

Depends on a new release of browserid-crypto incorporating https://github.com/mozilla/browserid-verifier/issues/69 (so the tests might fail here for a bit...)
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Allow IdPs to publish multiple public keys.

This allows the IdP support document to include a 'keys'
property containing a list of public keys, any of which
could be used to produce a valid signature.  IdPs might like
to use this during e.g. key rotation events.

pullsbody:
The latest browserid-crypto removed support for "new format"
certificates and assertions, which required some slight tweaks to the
tests.

We _could_ keep the "RSA"/"DSA" compatability hooks for algorithm name as part of browserid-crypto, which would make this PR just a version bump.  But IIUC they were never used in the wild, so it seems prudent to be strict and catch potential incompatibilities early.

@fmarier r? in combination with https://github.com/mozilla/browserid-crypto/pull/103
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Update to latest browserid-crypto.

The latest browserid-crypto removed support for "new format"
certificates and assertions, which required some slight tweaks to the
tests.

pullsbody:
This updates the jwcrypto dependency to v0.5.1, which includes some changes to the way errors are reported:
- It returns Error objects rather than strings; we should do the same here but for this deployment let's just normalize them back to strings
- It no longer distinguishes between "certificate expired" and "assertion expired" in the error message

Let's get the latest into prod and then file a follow-up bug to keep improving the error/logging situation across all these projects.

@francois r?
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Update jwcrypto dependency to v0.5.1

pullsbody:
A recent change caused audience mismatch error messages to go from this:

```
"audience mismatch: domain mismatch"
```

To this:

```
"audience misatch: Error: domain mismatch"
```

This repo didn't have tests for the error message, but browserid-verify does and they started failing when I updated the dependency there.  This PR restores the messages to their previous value, which IMHO is nicer.  It also adds some tests and fixes a test that should have been failing, but wasn't.

@fmarier r?
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Restore audience-mismatch errors to previous behaviour, add tests.

pull_commit_message:
Be more strict about the format of "disabled"

While we could be more tolerant here than in the spec, the risk is
that the majority of developers will not read the spec and will
instead try something with our verifier and expect that it will
always continue to work the same way.

In other words, if we're too lenient at the start, we will be
stuck supporting an alternative syntax forever and will impose that
on third-party verifiers as well.

pullsbody:
This is a proposal for dealing with https://github.com/mozilla/browserid-verifier/issues/13 in a mildly generic way, by implementing support for the $https_proxy and $no_proxy environment variables.  These are used by at least `wget` and the python standard library to control proxying behaviour so using them here seems at least semi-standards-compliant.

Thoughts?

Possible improvements might include:  add a config option to explicitly disable them; process them once at startup rather than string-munging for each request.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Transparently support $https_proxy and $no_proxy environment variables.

pullsbody:
This is a proposal for dealing with https://github.com/mozilla/browserid-verifier/issues/13 in a mildly generic way, by implementing support for the $https_proxy and $no_proxy environment variables.  These are used by at least `wget` and the python standard library to control proxying behaviour so using them here seems at least semi-standards-compliant.

Thoughts?

Possible improvements might include:  add a config option to explicitly disable them; process them once at startup rather than string-munging for each request.

pull_commit_message: Add more tests for correct $HTTPS_PROXY use.

schemes:
- http://

- app://

pulltitle: always throw Errors instead of Strings
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: always throw Errors instead of Strings

pullsbody:
While we could be more tolerant here than in the spec, the risk is
that the majority of developers will not read the spec and will
instead try something with our verifier and expect that it will
always continue to work the same way.

In other words, if we're too lenient at the start, we will be
stuck supporting an alternative syntax forever and will impose that
on third-party verifiers as well.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Add a test to make sure that "disabled: false" works

pullsbody:
While we could be more tolerant here than in the spec, the risk is
that the majority of developers will not read the spec and will
instead try something with our verifier and expect that it will
always continue to work the same way.

In other words, if we're too lenient at the start, we will be
stuck supporting an alternative syntax forever and will impose that
on third-party verifiers as well.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Be more strict about the format of "disabled"

While we could be more tolerant here than in the spec, the risk is
that the majority of developers will not read the spec and will
instead try something with our verifier and expect that it will
always continue to work the same way.

In other words, if we're too lenient at the start, we will be
stuck supporting an alternative syntax forever and will impose that
on third-party verifiers as well.

pullsbody:
Let's do this closer to the data, not deep into the callers of the
well-known parser.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Validate provisioning and authentication endpoints

Let's do this closer to the data, not deep into the callers of the
well-known parser.

pulltitle: Eliminate a variable reuse in claims extraction
pullsbody:
These two sets of claims should always be kept completely separate
so let's use separate variables at all times when handling them.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Eliminate a variable reuse in claims extraction

These two sets of claims should always be kept completely separate
so let's use separate variables at all times when handling them.

pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message: Remove bogus comments (copy/paste leftovers)

pulltitle: Validate the authority field for delegating IdPs
pullsbody:
The validation of that field should happen in the parser so that
invalid values never make it to the callers.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Validate the authority field for delegating IdPs

The validation of that field should happen in the parser so that
invalid values never make it to the callers.

pulltitle: Make the redirect check more precise
pullsbody:
HTTP 304 (Not Modified) and 305 (Use Proxy) are not redirects so
they should probably not get the "redirects not allowed" error
message.

Not sure about 300 (Multiple Choices), but I left it out as well.
pull_repo_desc: BrowserID library used by the Firefox Accounts verifier
pull_commit_message:
Make the redirect check more precise

HTTP 304 (Not Modified) and 305 (Use Proxy) are not redirects so
they should probably not get the "redirects not allowed" error
message.

Not sure about 300 (Multiple Choices), but I left it out as well.
